awd_titl_txt: RoL: EAGER: DESYN-C3 Membraneless organelles by design: a biomimetic approach
awd_abstract_narration:
The cell has to organize a large number of reactions. It accomplishes this by isolating certain reactions and molecules inside of compartments known as organelles. Sometimes these organelles exist within membranes. Sometimes they exist simply as a distinct liquid phase. Controlling organelle formation and composition is central to creating a synthetic cell.  Synthetic cells could be used in the biomanufacturing of chemicals, biofuels, and therapeutics, among potential applications. This project will investigate whether synthetic organelles without membranes can house complex reaction sequences. High school students will be involved in this project directly, through hands-on training in synthetic biology and participation in the international genetically engineered machine (iGEM) competition. Their challenge will be to develop protein tags that can trigger formation of the liquid phase organelles. They will also share their experiences on a blog. This will hopefully increase their enthusiasm and interest in pursuing careers in STEM-related fields.

Liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) of proteins is a fundamental process in living cells. It underpins the formation of functional, non-membrane bound, liquid-like compartments involved in cell function and development. Examples include the nucleolus, Cajal bodies, nuclear speckles, germ granules, processing bodies, stress granules, and cell signaling compartments. These membraneless organelles can separate and concentrate specific sets of molecules in a highly dynamic manner. They also exchange components with their microenvironments rapidly. Within the liquid droplet, proteins maintain or acquire a folded structure, and conserve functions such as specific protein recognition. Increasingly, these structures are being implicated in diseases caused by protein aggregation. In this project, we will test whether LLPS can be exploited to enhance catalysis. An organelle that brings together elements of an enzyme cascade will be constructed and evaluated. These membraneless organelles will be evaluated by expressing the modular proteins in vivo and visualizing the formation of LLPS droplets by microscopy. Further, we will extend this approach to enable enzymatic cascades that include artificial metalloenzymes. If successful, this proposal will establish an innovative, simple method to generate organelles for synthetic biology, complementing existing methods such as encapsulation by protein shells or by vesicles.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored how liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) of intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) can be used to assemble microreactors through co-localization of enzymes and substrates in vitro with potential applications in vivo.

For many IDPs known to exhibit LLPS, formation of phase-separated liquid droplets can be controlled in vitro with external parameters such as temperature and salt concentration. These processes are also observed in living cells, for example, in response to cellular stress that results in the formation of phase-separated liquid droplets called stress granules. However, the specific biological function of stress granules remains under debate.

IDPs in phase-separated liquid droplets form a separate liquid phase with a high protein concentration within the remaining solution and can be qualitatively compared to phase-separated oil droplets in water. However, the interior environment of IDP-rich protein droplets is not necessarily hydrophobic. Instead, IDPs prone to undergo LLPS are often polar and feature many charged residues.

Our initial strategy was to covalently link enzymes to IDPs. LLPS triggered by changes in external parameters such as temperature or salt concentration would thus allow concentrating enzymes in the phase-separated liquid droplets. Simultaneous co-localization of enzymes from a reaction cascade (the product of one enzymatically catalyzed reaction serves as substrate for another reaction catalyzed by a different enzyme) has the potential to substantially increase overall reaction rates due to reduced diffusion requirements. Further, the reaction could be stopped or slowed down by a second change in temperature or salt concentration to reverse LLPS.

One outcome of this project is the observation of spontaneous partitioning of enzymes into phase-separated liquids without covalent linkage to droplet-forming IDPs. We observed this behavior for our test system consisting of the enzyme horse radish peroxidase and the IDP DDX4. This observation is intriguing in the context of possible biological roles of stress granules. The partitioning of mRNA into stress granules has been frequently reported, but our observation indicates that the composition of stress granules may be more complex. Further, spontaneous partitioning of our test enzymes into phase-separated DDX4 droplets enables experiments without the covalent linkage, which avoids potential risks of adversely affecting enzyme activity.

We characterized the phase separation of DDX4 primarily using dynamic light scattering (DLS), which can detect the formation of oligomeric protein states and is highly sensitive to an increase in turbidity of the solution in response to the formation of liquid droplets. Previous studies of the phase diagram of DDX4 solutions have been based on macroscopically distinguishable phases and were not sensitive to microscopic precursors of phase-separation and droplet size distributions. We observed phase separation under high salt concentrations (500mM) for which the phase separation temperature is close to room temperature. During temperature scans to induce LLPS, we observed a tendency of the system to form nanometer-sized aggregates that precede the formation of liquid droplets as well indications of irreversible aggregation processes. These observations are highly sensitive to individual parameters of the experiment including protein purification and storage as well as the rate of change in temperature during measurements. These factors limited the determination of a precise phase transition temperature for future applications in living systems for which variations of external parameters to trigger liquid droplet formation are more limited than in in vitro systems. However, our results demonstrated a previously unknown complexity of DDX4 solutions that extends beyond the co-existence of a dilute solution and phase-separated liquid droplets.

In addition to DLS, we utilized confocal microscopy with the support of external collaborators to characterize LLPS in DDX4 solutions. Here, dyes that spontaneously partition into phase-separated liquid droplets provided us with a direct tool to observe droplet formation in solution.

Accompanying the experiments, we developed a novel simulation approach to study LLPS in IDP solutions. Our goal was to construct a model capable to simulate the formation of phase-separated liquid droplets on a 100 nanometer length scale (see Figure), while simultaneously being sensitive to details of the simulated IDP sequences. To achieve this, we used a multiscale modeling strategy in which a coarse-grained model from the literature with a sequence-specific potential (1 bead per amino acid) was used to determine effective protein-protein interaction potentials (see Figure). These effective potentials were then used in a super-coarse-grained model, in which protein particles are reduced to single particles. We investigated the limits of such a model to describe LLPS and identified multiple mechanisms to include entropic penalties associated with the high density of IDPs in liquid droplets, which are not captured by pairwise additive protein-protein interaction potentials. Our insights from this modelling approach provide us with new strategies for the modeling of complex biomolecular systems on length and time scales not yet accessible to fine-grained or atomistic simulation models.
